Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Small-Scale Low-Temperature Multiple Effect Distillation for Brackish Groundwater Desalination Using Heat from Biomass Pyrolysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a new kind of water desalination system that operates on renewable energy and is suitable for the small scale: individual farms or processing facilities, or small groups of houses. This system combines beneficial use of solid biomass wastes with production of high purity water and a marketable biochar co-product that can be used to offset water treatment costs. This project may enable feasible water desalination for those with difficult-to-treat, hard brackish water and those without easy access to the electricity or the replacement membranes needed for reverse osmosis systems. Water desalination is a multi-billion dollar industry worldwide and is growing steadily to meet expanding demands for fresh water. New system designs create more options for the industry to find environmentally and economically sustainable water treatment solutions.

This I-Corps project is focused on the identification of end users and potential licensees for a low-temperature multiple effect distillation (MED) system that derives its energy from pyrolysis of waste biomass such as agricultural residues, food processing wastes, and urban yard waste. In MED systems, heat is used to boil water and the heat of boiling is recycled from one evaporator to another. Advantages of low-temperature MED operation conditions are that hard brackish water is less likely to scale, hot water from a variety of potential sources can be used for the heat of boiling, and there are no membranes to replace. Current research has focused on the chemical engineering simulation of the entire pyrolysis-MED process and the development of a laboratory-scale prototype to study the effects of water chemistry on desalination performance. Early results suggest that this type of unit has strong potential for use in areas with limited access to reliable electricity and abundant supplies of unused biomass such as rural agricultural communities, especially in the developing world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF I-Corps™ program, the Aggie MED team developed a Business Model Canvas for the biomass pyrolysis-multiple effect distillation waste management and water desalination concept. They completed 106 customer interviews during the seven week period in five states and in Mexico. Customers included large and small-scale farmers and ranchers, civil and environmental engineers, brewery and water treatment equipment suppliers, water analysis and treatment service company managers, biomass and municipal waste valorization entrepreneurs, and international development/NGO personnel.

The original technology concept was the coupling of biomass waste utilization through slow pyrolysis to produce heat energy and biochar with a thermal-based water desalination method called multiple effect distillation (MED) that produces purified water through reusing the heat of boiling. Because the system used heat energy instead of high pressure pumps and membranes as in reverse osmosis, the pyrolysis-MED was expected to be more suitable for small-scale operations.

Through conducting the customer discovery interviews, the team learned that there is substantial demand for biomass waste management and for water desalination but the scales of these demands did not match for most customers: those with excess biomass frequently had few issues with water quality or quantity, while those that had water quality issues, frequently did not have enough biomass to supply the needed energy. Relatively high-quality water is available to most customers from municipal utilities at prices that do not justify purchasing and maintaining in-house water treatment equipment. Even in areas with a relative scarcity of high-quality water, the capital investment and maintenance for a water desalination system could not be justified within the customer’s business model at the present time; it was more cost-effective to live with the negative impacts of the brackish water than to implement a water treatment system. Energy costs in the U.S. are low enough that obtaining electricity from the grid is more economical than producing electricity and/or heat from available biomass wastes.

From the information gathered at the customer discovery interviews, the team concluded that there is potential for a pyrolysis-MED system in some developing countries but that the market is not large enough to support a small business in that area without extensive collaborations with local governments and international aid/development organizations. Instead, the team would redirect its research efforts on other problems faced by customers: operation of water desalination systems for hard brackish water chemistries that result in system fouling, techno-economic analysis decision-making tools for agricultural producers facing water salinity issues, and use of biomass wastes to produce electricity in developing countries and rural areas where electricity is a substantial portion of the facility’s operating costs. Customer interviews have resulted in three additional collaborative projects with NMSU engineering students, and multiple case studies and example problems for use in chemical engineering core courses. The entrepreneurial lead (EL) for the team is in the process of completing his PhD dissertation and associated journal manuscripts for publication related to this project.
